awd_titl_txt: RUI: Unusual Oxidation and Domino Reactions via Palladium-catalyzed α-Heteroarylation of Ketones
awd_abstract_narration:
Unusual Oxidation and Domino Reactions via Palladium-catalyzed alpha-Heteroarylation of Ketones

The preparation of organic chemicals using palladium catalysts continues to grow in importance in both fundamental research and industry. Reactions catalyzed by palladium are extremely useful and used in many different fields of chemistry such as basic chemicals, dyes, organic light emitting diodes, crop protection chemicals, and pharmaceutical agents. To further improve and expand these catalytic reactions, it is imperative to develop a fundamental understanding of the underlying chemistry in order to discover new chemical transformations, produce fewer byproducts, and generate less waste. In this project, Dr. Lili Ma is investigating two types of palladium-catalysis, oxidations and domino (sequential reaction steps) reactions. Spectroscopic techniques are being used to understand the fundamental steps of these reactions, and their applications in green chemistry, ligand design, biochemistry, and medicinal chemistry are also being explored. Dr. Ma is actively engaged in STEM research activities such as an international summer research intern program and UR-STEM summer research program for students without previous research experience. Dr. Ma is also highly involved in STEM outreach activities such as the STEM day for grade school students, STEM expo day, and the Saturday Program for Access to Rewarding Knowledge (SPARK) to improve the education for grade school and high school students. 

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Lili Ma of Northern Kentucky University is developing palladium catalysts for unusual oxidation reactions and domino reactions via direct á-heteroarylation of ketones. The first reaction under investigation is a Pd-catalyzed, microwave-assisted synthesis of 1,2-diketones. The 1,2-diketone products are applied to the synthesis of versatile building blocks which include heterocyclic rings, diamines and diimines. The second reaction under investigation is a Pd-catalyzed microwave-assisted, one-pot domino approach for the synthesis of heteroaryl isocoumarin derivatives. These efficient organic reactions provide convenient access to building blocks which are useful for applications ranging from materials chemistry to medicinal chemistry. Studies of the catalytic cycle are being probed using 1H and 31P NMR techniques to gain insights on the reaction mechanisms. Dr. Ma is an active participant in the STEM research and outreach programs. In support of the broader impacts of the project, her research activities in conjunction with the department and university STEM programs provide opportunities to recruit and retain female students, first-generation college students and African American/Latino research students in the STEM disciplines.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Palladium, a rare earth metal, is widely used in many aspects of our lives such as automotive catalytic converters, surgical instruments, electronic contacts, etc. Palladium plays an important role in chemical transformation by serving as a catalyst that helps bring two components together to form new molecules. One interesting and valuable class of organic molecules is heterocyclic compounds, which contain non-carbon heteroatoms such as nitrogen, sulfur, and oxygen. Heterocyclic compounds are pervasive in natural products, drugs, biological systems, and synthetic chemicals. The function and importance of heterocyclic molecules rely heavily on these heteroatoms. However, there are many challenges in synthesizing heterocyclic compounds due to catalyst degradation, toxic reaction conditions, laborious purification, etc.

This award has contributed significantly to our research on the synthesis of heterocyclic compounds catalyzed by palladium. Specifically, three palladium-catalyzed reactions have been developed in our lab: the direct heteroarylation to synthetize valuable ketones as organic reaction precursors, the heteroarylation/oxidation sequence to synthesize heteroaryl 1,2-diketones as 1,2-dielectrophiles for condensation reactions, and the domino reaction to synthesize heteroaryl isocoumarin derivatives as anti-breast cancer candidates. When compared with the traditional methods, these new methods show better efficiency, greater compatibility, and more environmentally friendly natures in making new chemical transformations. The methods developed in this study expanded the types of reactions palladium can catalyze and provided mechanistic insights into the roles of palladium catalysts, ligands, and bases. It also provided rapid access to useful molecules in medicinal chemistry since heterocyclic compounds are one of the most significant architectural cores of pharmaceuticals. Additionally, the development of the palladium catalytic system under microwave irradiation is important for green industrial chemistry as it requires less chemicals, produces fewer byproducts and generates less chemical waste.

This NSF-supported research not only explored a new catalytic system, but also provided excellent research opportunities for NKU undergraduate students, especially women, under-represented minorities, and first-generation students. Undergraduate research students were exposed to frontier discoveries in organic chemistry and medicinal chemistry. They developed skills in the usage of modern instrumentation and digital tools, and they developed their scientific collaboration and communication skills. Being involved in research, they realized that they made important contributions to the field of organic chemistry, and they shared the excitement of discovery in this scientific field. The independent research experience has inspired and prepared research students for their future graduate programs, professional schools, scientific and engineering careers. Throughout the course of this research, eighteen undergraduate students have been involved in this project. Three undergraduate co-authored manuscripts have been published in peer-reviewed journals. Eight students have presented their research discoveries at American Chemical Society national meetings. About half of the graduated research students have continued their studies in graduate or professional schools including the University of Oregon Graduate School, the University of Florida Graduate School, and Harvard Medical School. 

Finally, educational opportunities were derived from this project by incorporating faculty research into lab courses. The success of this awarded research provided a unique opportunity to develop an organic chemistry sophomore lab curriculum at NKU using the Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CURE) approach. A real-world authentic research problem, to modify natural products using the palladium-catalyzed heteroarylation reaction established in this project, was utilized in this CURE course. The most significant impact was that it provided increased accessibility to authentic research experiences to more lab students since the sophomore organic lab student body is much larger than that of upper division labs or in traditional research groups. Finishing this research course enhanced students? laboratory skills, increased students? learning and collaboration abilities, and inspired their interest in careers in science. This innovative pedagogy approach has impacted over twenty undergraduate lab students each year since its implementation in fall 2020.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: Lili Ma

Image
  • Our research discovery on the palladium-catalyzed heteroarylation was selected as Cover Art of the Journal of Organic Chemistry
    Lili Ma
    Lili Ma
    JOC cover art
